doc.title: EMBOSS

description.text: European Molecular Biology Open Software Suite

doc.reference: EMBOSS: The European Molecular Biology Open Software Suite (2000) Rice,P. Longden,I. and Bleasby, A. Trends in Genetics 16, (6) pp276--277

fieldset.title: This parameter is mandatory
fieldset.data-formats: EMBL FASTA GCG GENBANK NBRF CODATA RAW SWISSPROT GFF

xhtml:div.label: Translation frames (value from 1 to 6) 1 2 3 Forward three frames -1 -2 -3 Reverse three frames All six frames

Genetic codes Standard Standard (with alternative initiation codons) Vertebrate mitochondrial Yeast mitochondrial Mold, protozoan, coelenterate mitochondrial and mycoplasma/spiroplasma Invertebrate mitochondrial Ciliate macronuclear and dasycladacean Echinoderm mitochondrial Euplotid nuclear Bacterial Alternative yeast nuclear Ascidian mitochondrial Flatworm mitochondrial Blepharisma macronuclear Chlorophycean mitochondrial Trematode mitochondrial Scenedesmus obliquus Thraustochytrium mitochondrial

Regions to translate (eg: 4-57,78-94)?
Regions to translate. If this is left blank, then the complete sequence is translated. A set of regions is specified by a set of pairs of positions. The positions are integers. They are separated by any non-digit, non-alpha character. Examples of region specifications are: 24-45, 56-78 1:45, 67=99;765..888 1,5,8,10,23,45,57,99 Note: you should not try to use this option with any other frame than the default, -frame=1

Trim trailing x's and *'s?
Yes No
This removes all 'X' and '*' characters from the right end of the translation. The trimming process starts at the end and continues until the next character is not a 'X' or a '*'

Change all *'s to x's?
Yes No
This changes all STOP codon positions from the '*' character to 'X' (an unknown residue). This is useful because some programs will not accept protein sequences with '*' characters in them.

Define frame '-1' as starting in the last codon?
Yes No
The default definition of frame '-1' is the reverse-complement of the set of codons used in frame 1. (Frame -2 is the set of codons used by frame 2, similarly frames -3 and 3). This is a common standard, used by the Staden package and other programs. If you prefer to define frame '-1' as using the set of codons starting with the last codon of the sequence, then set this to be true.
Name of the output sequence file (e_outseq)
Choose the sequence output format Embl Fasta Gcg Genbank Nbrf Codata Raw Swissprot Gff

div.title: This parameter is mandatory
div.data-formats: EMBL FASTA GCG GENBANK NBRF CODATA RAW SWISSPROT GFF

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Regions to translate. If this is left blank, then the complete sequence is translated. A set of regions is specified by a set of pairs of positions. The positions are integers. They are separated by any non-digit, non-alpha character. Examples of region specifications are: 24-45, 56-78 1:45, 67=99;765..888 1,5,8,10,23,45,57,99 Note: you should not try to use this option with any other frame than the default, -frame=1
This removes all 'X' and '*' characters from the right end of the translation. The trimming process starts at the end and continues until the next character is not a 'X' or a '*'
This changes all STOP codon positions from the '*' character to 'X' (an unknown residue). This is useful because some programs will not accept protein sequences with '*' characters in them.

The default definition of frame '-1' is the reverse-complement of the set of codons used in frame 1. (Frame -2 is the set of codons used by frame 2, similarly frames -3 and 3). This is a common standard, used by the Staden package and other programs. If you prefer to define frame '-1' as using the set of codons starting with the last codon of the sequence, then set this to be true.

div.title: This parameter is mandatory
div.data-formats: EMBL FASTA GCG GENBANK NBRF CODATA RAW SWISSPROT GFF

format.code: ("", " -frame=" + str(value))[value is not None and value!=vdef]
